The Shakespeare Monologue is one of our school's co-curricular programs.For the past few years, a handful of students (sometimes two handfuls) in grades 5-8 have given up their lunchtime once a week to prepare to compete in the Regional Shakespeare Monologue Competition.

Students virtually performed monologues from shows including MACBETH, AS YOU LIKE IT and ALL‚Äôs WELL THAT ENDS WELL for a panel of guest judges from the local and Pittsburgh theater communities. After a very close competition, Miss. Hinkelman is pleased to announce that Logan R was this year‚Äôs winner for her performance of one of Benedick‚Äôs monologues from MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING. She will be awarded a $25 gift card in honor of her win.

A message from Miss. Hinkelman
This group has been extremely supportive of and kind to each other throughout the process, and their commitment and work ethic have been exemplary. I will miss the eighth graders, but I look forward to the return of the rest of the crew and the addition of new competitors next year!

Way to go, Scholars!

On Monday, May 11th, our 3rd graders enjoyed a special treat! Dr. Lewis Owen (pictured below), professor and head of the department of Marine, Earth, and Atmospheric Science at North Carolina State University, was a guest speaker during their science class. Dr. Owen talked with the students via Zoom. He discussed how earthquakes are formed, what regions of the planet have the most activity and why. This Zoom was an extension of an Earth Science unit students completed earlier this year. Dr. Owen was highly complimentary of the students' knowledge, questions, and manners. Special thanks to Dr. Owen for sharing his time and expertise with our students!
Another guest speaker is planned for next week who will integrate science and math. He will teach the students how to use their knowledge of probability to beat the odds on games at The North Carolina State Fair. Way to keep learning, SA!

4. Submit your side by side image with subject line: RECREATE to smile@scholarsacademy.org.
We can't wait to see your re-creations, SA!

SA FAMILY FUN FRIDAYS IDEAS
As we head in to the weekend, here are a couple of ideas for some at home family fun:
YOGA JENGA - Using a sharpie, mark each Jenga block with the name of a yoga pose (see picture provided). Set up your Jenga for usual game play. During each person's turn, remove a block carefully without tumbling the tower. Then, the player demonstrates the pose written on their block. If the tower tumbles, the player tries to hold the pose for 30 seconds.
No Jenga set - no problem. Using regular blocks, an assortment of boxes, etc. mark each item with a yoga pose and take turns using one item to help build a structure and demonstrate the name of your yoga pose. Once the structure is finished, everyone holds the last item's yoga pose for 30 seconds.
EASY DIY BIRD FEEDER - Use any plastic bottle and up cycle for a feeder for your feathered friends:
https://www.todaysparent.com/family/crafts/craft-bird-feeder/

If you have a fun family activity you'd like to share, send your idea to smile@scholarsacademy.org.

Stay safe & healthy, SA!

post_text: Our 4th graders are learning all about food nutrients, as well as food safety and the importance of the 4 C's (Chill, Clean, Cook, and Combat Cross Contamination). Recently, students conducted a few science activities/experiments on these topics. First they learned about sugar and predicted how much sugar is found in different drinks. Then, they did an experiment to determine how much iron is in different types of cereal using magnetism. And this week, students worked in groups to look for bacteria growth in pasteurized milk and UHT (ultra high temperature) milk when they are exposed to cold temperature and room temperature. Hands on science is awesome!

post_text: Special thanks to special guest, Dr. Tony George, retired NFL player turned philanthropist and inspirational speaker. Dr. George has a doctorate in Divinity and believes we should all accept and celebrate each other‚Äôs differences. Using the acronym CARE, Dr. George talked about how we should strive to comfort, accept, reassure, and educate one another. Using a squat exercise, he asked students and staff to try to hold the squat for a minute, which was hard. He then asked all to reflect on the discomfort or pain they may have felt and how we each may experience that differently. The key message being to practice CARE in our daily life. Thanks again for sharing your time with our 4th-6th grade students!
